title: 107_hr3782
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Clean, Learn, Educate, Abolish, Neutralize, and Undermine Production (CLEAN-UP) of Methamphetamines Act of 2002". The table of contents includes sections on environmental protection. The "Clean, Learn, Educate, Abolish, Neutralize, and Undermine Production (CLEAN-UP) of Methamphetamines Act of 2002" includes sections on response to environmental hazards associated with illegal manufacture of methamphetamine on Department of Agriculture and Department of the Interior lands, grant programs for State and local government and private response, designation of by-products of methamphetamine laboratories as hazardous materials, and grant programs for local law enforcement agencies for cleanup and disposal of methamphetamine laboratories. Grant program to assist local law enforcement agencies in meeting the costs of complying with Federal laws relating to methamphetamine laboratory cleanup and disposal. Study of environmental impact. TITLE III--ENFORCEMENT
Sec. 201. Study on health effects of exposure to methamphetamine manufacturing.
Sec. 202. Grants for educational programs on methamphetamine prevention and treatment.
Sec. 203. Local grants for methamphetamine abuse treatment. TITLE I--ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION
Sec. 101. Response to environmental hazards associated with illegal manufacture of methamphetamine on Department of Agriculture and Department of the Interior lands. Sec. 102 authorizes a grant program to aid state and local governments and private entities in responding to environmental hazards from methamphetamine production on agricultural lands. $15,000,000 is authorized for this purpose. The Secretary of Agriculture may grant funds to clean up contaminated agricultural lands from methamphetamine production. $15,000,000 is authorized for this purpose. By-products of methamphetamine labs are designated as hazardous materials under certain acts. The Secretary of Transportation and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency designate by-products of methamphetamine production as hazardous materials and waste under specific acts to protect the environment and impose penalties on illegal lab operators. The Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration will submit a list of harmful by-products from methamphetamine production to the Secretary of Transportation and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency to prevent environmental damage. The list will be updated annually to reflect changes in the production process. The Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration will submit a list of harmful by-products from methamphetamine production to the Secretary of Transportation and the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency for designation within 18 months of the enactment of the Act. Additional designations will be made if the list is revised. SEC. 104. Grant program to assist local law enforcement agencies in safe identification, cleanup, and disposal of methamphetamine laboratories. The Secretary of Labor will provide grants for training and equipment for this purpose. $20,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2003. SEC. 105. Grant program to assist local law enforcement agencies in complying with federal laws on methamphetamine laboratory cleanup and disposal. The Secretary of Labor will provide grants for this purpose, with $10,000,000 authorized for fiscal year 2003. Rulemaking may be prescribed to carry out this section. The Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency is required to conduct a study on the environmental impact of methamphetamine laboratories, including effects on agriculture. $1,000,000 is authorized for this study in fiscal year 2003. Additionally, a study on the health effects of exposure to the unlawful manufacture of methamphetamine is mandated. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on the contamination of food, water, air, soil, and equipment by methamphetamine manufacturing, and the resulting health effects. A report describing the findings will be submitted to Congress within one year. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include grants for educational programs on prevention and treatment of methamphetamine abuse. $20,000,000 is allocated for fiscal year 2003 for these grants. Subpart 4 is renamed to Subpart 5, and a new section on Education on Prevention and Treatment of Methamphetamine Abuse is added. This includes a grant program under section 4146. The Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include grants for educational programs on prevention and treatment of methamphetamine abuse. The Secretary may make grants to local educational agencies and nonprofit organizations for programs on methamphetamine abuse prevention and treatment. Applicants must submit an application to receive a grant under this section. Subpart 1 of part B of title V of the Public Health Service Act is amended to include local grants for treatment of methamphetamine abuse and related conditions. The Secretary may provide grants for treatment of methamphetamine abuse to political subdivisions and nonprofit entities, including services for children exposed to harmful substances during methamphetamine manufacturing. The Secretary may provide grants for treatment of methamphetamine abuse to political subdivisions and nonprofit entities, including services for children exposed to harmful substances during methamphetamine manufacturing. Funding of $10,000,000 for fiscal year 2003 is authorized, with at least $2,500,000 reserved for children affected by methamphetamine manufacturing. TITLE III--ENFORCEMENT

SEC. 301. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR METHAMPHETAMINE LABORATORY SEIZURE STATISTICS: $2,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2003 for the collection, aggregation, and dissemination of methamphetamine laboratory seizure statistics by the El Paso Intelligence Center (EPIC) of the Department of Justice.

SEC. 302. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS FOR COPS GRANTS. Authorization of $20,000,000 for COPS grants in fiscal year 2003 to provide training for prosecution of methamphetamine offenses. $5,000,000 allocated for rural communities, and $2,000,000 for DEA reimbursement of training expenses. SEC. 303 expands the Methamphetamine Hot Spots Program to include personnel and equipment for enforcement, prosecution, and environmental cleanup of methamphetamine-affected areas. SEC. 304 authorizes appropriations for clandestine laboratory training. Authorized $10,000,000 for the Clandestine Laboratory Training Facility in Virginia to train law enforcement personnel nationwide. Also, added liability for promoters of drug-oriented entertainment under the Controlled Substances Act. SEC. 416A imposes penalties on promoters of drug-oriented entertainment events where controlled substances are knowingly used or distributed in violation of the law. Penalties include fines or imprisonment for up to 9 years. The Congress finds that pseudoephedrine is a key precursor chemical for making methamphetamine. Despite tighter controls in the US, large containers of pseudoephedrine from Canada still end up in meth labs, showing high demand. The Congress urges Canada to take immediate action to address the widespread availability of pseudoephedrine and its illegal importation into the United States, as Canada lacks a comprehensive legislative framework to combat the issue.
